text:
New @Mij_Europe client note - detects growing belief among Eurosceptics that May willing to deliver #Brexit via a 'no deal' "if that is what it takes". 

Makes it more likely ERG holds together in pursuit of a no deal.
author: pmdfoster

text: Agree. Slightly moot distinction. The EU is the public, lest we forget. And leaders represent and need the public. If the bus goes off the cliff it needs to be damned clear that there was a Brit at the wheel and the EU did everything to flag the hazards and provide an off-ramp
author: pmdfoster

text:
If MPs given legal guarantees they’d have role in trade mandate *might* there be a majority just for Withdrawal/Divorce deal? 

So, park the future to avoid cliff??? 

It’s an idea in play. Problem is backstop IS the future, but could this release the pressure???
author: pmdfoster

text: Very good question. They’ll have to climb a long way down to avoid this “no extension with elections” gambit. That’s a cliff edge of their making. They cd cut some time til June 30, but that’s corner we’re in.
author: pmdfoster

text: Understand that the concs are to be “legally formalised” today. So that confirms April 12 date. Later ones ultimately subject to events. Obvs U.K. must lay SI to fix U.K. end from Mar 29.
author: pmdfoster

text: Just carry on believing....I note how Mrs May didn’t even bother asking for single change to Withdrawal Agreement at EUCO.
author: pmdfoster

text:
U.K. MPs still dreaming. Please wake up. Repeat after me. 

THE. WITHDRAWAL. AGREEMENT. IS. CLOSED. 

Odds of clarity by April 12 if thinking is this confused is very, very low.
author: pmdfoster

text: Honestly wrong person to ask. All I understand is that lobby cores, EU27, EU Council and No10 think there no impediment to MV3

text: Seems like new dates will fix it. Bercow left himself wiggle room. No one on Parliament side seems to think it’s an issue now, or at least for now. Ask others about the technicals on that.

text: Fair.
author: pmdfoster

text: Very measured thread. Not sure EU has confidence in either Mrs May OR capacity of Parliament to over-rule her. But they’ve created flexible “no blame” space whatever the outcome.
author: pmdfoster

text: Nope. That’s the plan. A,B,C,D.....
author: pmdfoster

text:
This. Last night a carefully calibrated play from EU. 

- ensures no EU fingerprints on a ‘no deal’
- creates small space for Parliament to intervene and overrule Mrs May
- and mechanism to manage either outcome
author: pmdfoster

text: Save that Tweet for December.

text:
So @JamesCrisp6 asks Juncker and Tusk how long is a long extension?

Tusk doesn't answer. Juncker says "until the very end" [Laughter]
author: pmdfoster

text: So Donald Tusk @eucopresident makes clear for the record that he met with @theresa_may several times to get her to agree to the extension scenarios. No quibble guarantee.
author: pmdfoster

text:
Right. #Brexit #Article50 extension in summary. 

The new cliff edge is April 12, if MV3 is voted down. 

That gives May 12 extra days to say what next. 

If MV3 passes. It's to May 22
author: pmdfoster

text: I then moved to popularise the term in an interview with @BBCr4today on Monday 18th. Listen from 2h55. For the record. Lexicographers everywhere.  #brexit

author: pmdfoster

text: But in that scenario she stays for 14 days no? As lame duck. Unless there was some kind of uncontested defenestration, but Brexit wing wouldn't let that happen if it was possible (not sure it if is, procedurally in Tory Party. That takes us up to April 12 deadline.
author: pmdfoster

text: EU can make its views known, but UK must request and extension must be agreed unanimoulsy - inlcuding by departing MS. So Mrs May has a veto too.
author: pmdfoster

text: All I can say is that No10 has convinced EU side that they can/will hold MV3. Not sure the precise trick, but on that point they don't seem to have doubt
author: pmdfoster

text: Clincher?
author: pmdfoster

text: Aye. It's that nagging thought after what she said y'day. Would she? We are entering a very tight and febrile 24-48  hours at that point.
author: pmdfoster

text: All this.
author: pmdfoster

text: Either way next week is shaping up to be a real bottom-clencher. /8 ENDS
author: pmdfoster

text:
The risk to the EU is that May loses and then they don't get a coherent request for a long extension form @theresa_may.

Or she just asks for the same extension to June 30, or May 23 to keep trying. Would leaders go back on their stance this week? Maybe. /7
author: pmdfoster

text: From a purely Tory party perspective, viewed on a 5-10 year horizon, is delivering Brexit via a "managed" no deal not better than consigning it to the swamps of a long extension? /6
author: pmdfoster

text:
Time is very tight between her losing MV3 on Tuesday, say, and an emergency EU Council on Thursday.

No time for indicative votes, certainly. 

After all, May could argue that Parliament had been given ample opportunity to pass her deal.  /5
author: pmdfoster

text:
So that means that for the duration of the March 26-April 12 decision window, May is PM whatever happens.

Perhaps @bbclaurak @SamCoatesTimes @Steven_Swinford @GeorgeWParker know different?

How clear are we that May would not deliver Brexit via a 'no deal'?/4
author: pmdfoster

text:
How could Parliament stop her? 

Because if you believe EU red line on UK participating in EU elections is immovable then the deadline for that decision is April 12.

Even if May falls (she could lose a 'no confidence' vote whichever ways she breaks) she is PM for 14 days. /3
author: pmdfoster

text:
She said: "As prime minister I could not consider a further delay beyond 30 June." 

People took that to mean she would resign.

But it could also mean, she would opt for a 'no deal' (Party unity over country) over a long extension. /2
author: pmdfoster

text:
A thought/question, oh #Brexit Twitter about what happens if the Withdrawal Agrement is voted down again next week.

How does @theresa_may get sent back to Brussels to ask for an extension she says she will not ask for? 1/Thread
author: pmdfoster

text: Fabulous.
author: pmdfoster

text:
So @adamfleming on @BBCr4today imagining forward to the Thursday emergency #EUCO if #MV3 fails, with one day to go. “Makes me feel ill”. 

Me too. @MishalHusainBBC asks what EU would do? Secondary question. First is what wound UK do?
author: pmdfoster

author: pmdfoster

text: This. Of course May cd go the other way. She won’t be the PM that asks for long extension, but that cd still be because she opts for No Deal. Devil’s advocate.
author: pmdfoster

text: True. And U.K. officials say there’s a lot of this about. Lidington pushing back hard on this yday understand. Seems like a useful pretext to me.
author: pmdfoster

text:
Macron to say 'non' to #Brexit extension? Or just 'non' unless May has passed Withdrawal Deal. More bellicose noises from Paris. 

https://www.lepoint.fr/politique/emmanuel-berretta/emmanuel-macron-refuse-de-reporter-la-date-du-brexit-20-03-2019-2302680_1897.php …
author: pmdfoster

text: Yes. That final para "I am confident" ...you can feel hearts sinking.
author: pmdfoster

text:
Commission might say that. Might want to 'reward' those who prepared.

But MS reps, when theyspeak frankly, are very clear they aren't ready; don't want to be blamed for 'no deal'.

Even if some say a 'no deal is better than a bad extension'
author: pmdfoster

text: But not by the right 'sources' I don't think. Least doesn't feel that way from MS, Cion and Council Secretariat. The Parliament is, well, the Parliament.
author: pmdfoster

text:
As I said at the top, the situation is very fluid. No crystal balls here. 

Maybe EU leaders are out of patience. Maybe Macron zeal wins over Merkel's innate caution? Lots of mixed messages about. Lots of static....but please stay tuned. ENDS/20
author: pmdfoster

text:
There has been talk of other 'fixes' - the UK appointing MEPs temporarily like an acceding state does - but talking to EU dips and officials it seems the mood is a million miles from that level of accommodation. 

"Nothing must 'infect' or destabilise the workings of the EU"/19
author: pmdfoster

text:
UK holding elections in June/Sept would be a ‘messy’ situation for the EU, sure.  

But would it be messier than a Brexit no deal? This is the question that EU leaders would have to grapple with. 

But it seems foremost a poltiical question, not a legal one/ 18
author: pmdfoster

text: If Member failed to hold elections they'd  end up in the European Court of Justice where an infringement proceeding would take place and a remedy sought. Which in this case would be an offer to hold European Elections as expeditiously as possible. If UK offered wd ECJ say no?/17
author: pmdfoster

text:
It was notable to see Martin Selmayor and European Parliament comms chief Jaume Duch openly disagreeing on Twitter this weekend. 

In short, a lot of Commission fretting over the elections is political spin over legal substance/16
author: pmdfoster

text: This is essentially a political question, since as UK officials point out, legally an EU member state that has failed to hold elections does not automatically tumble out of the EU. /15
author: pmdfoster

text: So if the British came back, say, on June 20 requesting a long extension (and agreeing to hold EU elections as expeditiously as possible) would the EU really say no? /14
author: pmdfoster

text: Which begs one more Q: If the EU granted the UK an extension to June 30 or May 22, and the deadline for notifying for EU elections passed on April 12 without the UK notifying its intention to hold the poll, would the EU really just sit and let the British go ‘off the cliff’? /13
author: pmdfoster

text: Alternatively, the EU could not take that risk and simply offer Mrs May a much shorter extension to April 12 to either pass her deal, or choose to go for a longer extension (with  above-noted conditions) if she fails. /13
author: pmdfoster

text: They could also, as @jamescrisp6 and I report,  insert a ‘mea culpa’ clause making plain that failure to hold those elections would entirely be the decision of the UK, and if it led to a ‘no deal’ that would be the UK’s fault, not Europe’s. /12
author: pmdfoster

text: This would set an effective deadline of April 12 for the UK to decide if it wanted a long extension, or wanted to ‘crash out’ without a deal on June 30 /11
author: pmdfoster

text: They may attach a rider noting that the UK must have held European Parliamentary elections on May 23-26 if they want to have a longer extension in the future. /10
author: pmdfoster

text:
So isn't that a pretty risk move by EU27?

Yes, and it is still possible EU leaders will take a different route when they meet on Thursday and agree to Mrs May’s request for an extension to June 30. 

French are pushing very hard line I hear, but Germans less so /9
author: pmdfoster

text: But that really is what one Tory peer just describd to me as "squeaky bum time", and notwithstanding clear majority in House against a 'no deal' it will require some brave interventions to stop it happening. The 'accidental' no deal cannot be ruled out. /8
author: pmdfoster

text:
Could she do this without splitting the party? Collapsing her government? 

A General Election would be a reason for a longer extension; or to explore an new (Norway) option that had demonstrated support in the House via indicative votes. /7
author: pmdfoster

text:
And if she loses in those circumstances, it gets even tighter.

May would need to go back to leaders and ask for the longer extension that sources told me an @JamedsCrisp6 that David Lidington was discussiong with ministers and officials before Cabinet shut him down. /6
author: pmdfoster

text:
But that is a high-risk strategy on EU side that isn't prepared for a 'no deal' (who is?) and would leave tiny window in the event May fails to win MV3.

Even if she wins the timetable for a statutory instrument inserting new leave date is tight. /5
author: pmdfoster

text:
Otherwise leaders would have to extension on her say-so. And let's face it, she hasn't inpsired confidence of late. 

So the EU could play it tough: if she gets the deal through, she gets the extension. If not, then not. /4
author: pmdfoster

text:
Not necessarily. As @adamfleming warned this AM - and later confirmed by @JunckerEU interview - EU may say a short extension is "conditional" on May passive her deal next week (presumed new vote Mon or Tues)

That would be a reason for a short extension/3
author: pmdfoster

text:
May will ask for extension to June 30, per reports. 

Less clear if she will also say UK prepared to 'no deal' on June 30. That might be a key omission to watch, on which more later. 

So will the EU agree? /2
author: pmdfoster

text:
Right #Brexit peeps, what is going on? What happens next? 

Short answer is its all pretty fluid, but here's what I think I know after usual chats with both etc (1/thread)
author: pmdfoster

text:
Now boo. Why ruin a good story like that. 

Next I'll learn that @JamesCrisp6 'Lewis Hamilton' pigeon didn't really sell for a million quid. 

As my old news editor used to say, sometimes you can make TOO many phone calls.
author: pmdfoster

text:
And if the car crashes after April 12, will EU really stick to guns on election point. 

That wd be political. Since legally, a member who fails to hold elections isn’t automatically tipped out of EU. Would go to court. But maybe the EU just says “enough”. 

Huge stakes.
author: pmdfoster

text: Indeed. May all about daily survival. But if EU sticks to need to participate in EU elex and she sticks to short request only (not what Lidington was sounding EU out on yday morning) then crunch is April 12 if deal fails again. Brave interventions will be required.
author: pmdfoster

text:
Latest from @Mij_Europe  

Troubles brewing on both side of Channel. Revolts in Westminster; hardening in Brussels - but if EU sticks to guns on particpation in EU elections whatever flavour or structure of extension, the key cut-off date remains April 12.
author: pmdfoster

text: Yes. That’s definitely in wind in Brussels. So if EU elex not on stock by April 11 (to access longer extension) then U.K. must be out by May 22 - ie before elex. That’s hardline position to reduce risk of accident if U.K. can stay to June 30. Whether that holds, less clear.
author: pmdfoster

text: What #Brexit giveth with one hand, it taketh away with the other.
author: pmdfoster

text: Yes. But if you start from principle of needing to hold EU elections...which requires notification by April 11, the rest flows from this basic stricture. However you structure #Article50 extension that remains pivotal decision point.
author: pmdfoster

text: The “young man from Whitehall”...he wasn’t that young...39 as it happened.
author: pmdfoster

text: Yes. It’ll be sold as a “flextension” is my guess, but in truth it’s a long extension that falls away when deal is agreed, which is legal fact anyway. So MPs get same choice. Deal pre April 11, or not and EU elex etc.
author: pmdfoster

text: I think not, from everything I hear. But always allow for leaders surprises. But don’t see the rationale. Think it’s clear cut choice. 3 months dead OR 9-12 months but holding EU elex.
author: pmdfoster

text: I hear same, despite some more bellicose noises in Paris - realism over pique. But of course @theresa_may shown limitless ability to make a hash of things.
author: pmdfoster

text: Yes. Coz A50 extension needs fixed end-date (or it would risk being start of endstate so illegal) the obvious thing is for leaders to say 9-12 months, but with EU elex required. That sets April 11 (or maybe 14) for make your mind up time.
author: pmdfoster

A second thought. Might the govt yet find a ruse to get round Bercow and hold MV3?

What about if deal with DUP (which seeks legally binding changes for Stormont Lock) did the trick? Or some other ruse?
author: pmdfoster

text: That's slightly in gift of Bercow...but yes, logically, or we're stuck.
author: pmdfoster

text:
Logically.

The Withdrawal Agreement is closed. 

The Political declaration is not.

To pass Bercow tests, we therefore need to change PD (CU, Norway) and test majority. 

The EU is clear it's happy to expand PD; fair to presume they will accommodate? 

#brexit
author: pmdfoster

text: Just when you thought it was safe to predict parameters of Extension discussions....    #Brexit

author: pmdfoster

text:
I understand some larger MS (including Germany) were arguing for some flexibility tonight for the reasons stated above. 

Tho a second source says it was the "least favoured" option (a flextension)..../9
author: pmdfoster

text:
OR would they - if the UK agreed expeditiously to hold elections and we presented clear reason (election, 2nd ref etc) say 'OK, as long as u hold elections ASAP'.

No certainty, but there is a certain amount of posturing going on here. /8
author: pmdfoster

text: Which makes me wonder, if the UK did want to revoke/seek longer extension and went to leaders and said, 'sorry, we sincerely meant to leave but these ERG types have bogged it all up"....would the really stand by and let the bus go off the cliff? /7
author: pmdfoster

text:
Because if the EU is really sticking to this then even revoking on June 30 is not possible (even tho ECJ gives us that unilateral right).

This is why I am told @MichelBarnier was urging EU ambos tonight not to grant a short extension beyond May 23 /6
author: pmdfoster

text:
The UK has not held EU elections. Therefore, at end of June 30....it's "sorry, we cannot render the EU unstable"...it's No Deal.

Mmmmm....this is when I start to wonder. How much of this is kidology? /5
author: pmdfoster

text:
So imagine this. 

May wins MV3, with reluctant ERG votes, by a small margin. Asks for June 30 extension for paperwork to be completed. 

Then the ERG revokes support..../4
author: pmdfoster

text:
It could also mean that IF May opts for short extension (to June 30) and we go past that April deadline, then May 23 elctions without participating, then there is NO WAY BACK. Eeek. 

Becuase if we get to June 29, and haven't held elections, then (on this basis) that's it. /3
author: pmdfoster

text:
The EU says it will be "legally unstable" if UK doesn't hold elections/have MEPs.

So that means if we want a long extension, we need to commit to hold EP elections on May 23. That means legislating in UK in April.

This cd put some heat on ERG/Brexiteers to back May deal. BUT/2
author: pmdfoster

text: The EU is focusing down on its choices for #Article50 extension - but that could create a serious potential for a 'no deal' cliff-edge at end of June. Bear with me. 1/Thread
author: pmdfoster
